results.name: Number of parts if 3^n is partitioned into parts of size 2^n as far as possible and into parts of size 1^n.
comment: Corresponds to the only solution of the Diophantine equation 3^n = x*2^n + y*1^n with constraint 0 <= y < 2^n. [Since 3^n is odd, of course y cannot be zero.)
link: Iain Fox, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..3322 (first 500 terms from Harry J. Smith)
formula: For n > 2, a(n) = 3^n mod (2^n-1). [_Alex Ratushnyak_, Jul 22 2012]
mathematica: f[n_] := Floor[3^n/2^n] + PowerMod[3, n, 2^n]; Array[f, 33] (* _Robert G. Wilson v_, Dec 27 2017 *)
program: (PARI) { for (n=1, 500, write("b060692.txt", n, " ", floor(3^n/2^n) + (3^n%2^n)); ) } \\ _Harry J. Smith_, Jul 09 2009
a060692 n = uncurry (+) $ divMod (3 ^ n) (2 ^ n)
